narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: greater knowledge on the social psychological research on prejudice, stereotyping and discrimination
We read and discussed a lot of literature on prejudice, implicit bias, societal racism, and the methods behind researching those topics.

A broad overview of the social psychology literature on prejudice, discrimination, and stereotyping.  Students are encouraged to think about the relevancy of such research to current intergroup tensions in society.
A really thorough understanding of the theories behind the causes and consequences of different forms of prejudice, as well as how to apply these theories to real world events.
We were able to learn about the psychological underpinnings of prejudice and how to communicate those underpinnings.
Fundamental knowledge on the social psychology of prejudice and discrimination, seminal experimental research, and applications to real-world scenarios

I learned how the current field of psychology of prejudice developed over the years, the methods used, the most prominent theories that explain how stereotyping, prejudice and discrimination occur at every stage of cognition and how to intervene.

I developed an ability to view and interpret modern political and social phenomenon through a psychological lens. The class gives a sound foundation in social psychology, but importantly it teaches you how to observe the affects of these theories in the real world, and how to counter them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The topics were interesting, the readings were relevant, and the class discussions were interesting. However, it was often difficult to contribute to the discussion since the professor and a few students would be talking for most of the time. It also felt like the topics focused mostly on theoretical concepts and social systems rather than the actual psychological processes and research, which is not entirely what I expected.

It is difficult to stay engaged because of the virtual format, though this is definitely not the fault of the teacher. It is also sometimes hard to be open about one's own experiences with prejudice and discrimination, though discussions about relevant personal experiences are very informative to the class. Perhaps an anonymous form to submit relevant personal experiences to be discussed in class could be useful? Unless you really want to emphasize that we should all be open and non-judgemental about our experience with prejudice and discrimination

Strengths: Prof. Richeson creates a really welcoming space for approaching sensitive topics, content is super relevant to events in the real world, syllabus manages to cover a lot of different theories in a short timeframe while still allowing for good engagement
Weaknesses: not really a weakness, but there is just so much to talk about related to prejudice that this class feels so short!

I really appreciated that we were given the opportunity to present on each weeks topics to our classmates. It offered the ability to dive deep into the material ourselves and take ownership over what we had learned.

The weekly discussions were very helpful for reinforcing course material, and each week was led by a different student group, which provided a greater level of engagement. I anticipate discussion would have gone smoother in a normal in-person semester without the technological limitations.
This is THE best class I have taken so far. The literature is up-to-date and very relevant to the current issues facing our society.

The strengths included Prof Richeson's incredibly generous and knowledgeable teaching style. She cares about each student and her subject deeply, and generates a passion for social psychology in her students. A weakness was that we could have heard more from hershe gets two students to lead the discussion each week, which can minimize her input (which is stellar when it occurs)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class was brilliant even while completely online.

There were often breakout rooms used throughout the course, which made it somewhat easier for discussion. It felt just as engaging as it probably would have been if it were in person. The class was very discussion-based rather than lecture-based, which made it a bit more interactive.

Overall professor Richardson did a very good job of encouraging class activities via student-directed discussions. Breakout rooms seemed to be very good in this class in particular, but it was probably because we were all so engaged with the subject matter and interested in what others thought of the topic at hand.

Con: Zoom seminars are, by nature, easier to 'clock out of.' It is simply harder to focus on a screen for two straight hours, and it's easier to get distracted. I wish we had the opportunity for a break in between. 

Pro: I still enjoyed the opportunity we had for discussion. I think our class did a good job of engaging in discussion and we still were able to have conversations virtually.  

Con: I was not the biggest fan of screensharing PowerPoints or Google Slides through Zoom because you either can't read the words very well or you can't see your classmates' faces. 

Pro: I liked the activities we did when we all wrote on the screen.

Prof. Richeson was always very caring and would start every class with check-ins, which really helped to not only foster a small community within the class but also helped for her to understand our own current (and usually very disparate) situations. She has always been caring first before anything else and was very flexible about deadlines and open to feedback along the way. It was a great class despite the circumstances!

I really appreciated that Prof. Richeson started every class with a group check-in -- I felt like I still got to know my classmates despite us never meeting in person, and it was nice to know that she, along with everyone in the class, was dealing with a lot of the same challenges that we were.
Professor Richeson was very accommodating in light of the pandemic.

Learning the course material and in-class reinforcement through discussion participation worked relatively well. During the COVID-19 pandemic, it was a little more difficult to gauge academic performance in the class since there were limited opportunities to receive feedback.
We did weekly check ins, which succeeded at creating a supportive atmosphere in the class and decreases the difficulty of sitting through two hours on zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES. Professor Richeson is incredible and the class atmosphere is perfect for anyone who loves deep conversation and reflection on current issues in our society.

I would recommend it for those who are interested in learning more about prejudice and how individual beliefs relate to society as a whole. You do not need a strong psychology background since it focuses mostly on societal issues and theories.

I would definitely recommend this course to any psychology student who is looking to explore the underlying psychological operations of how we perceive individuals and groups in light of past experiences with these people and how society has historically viewed them.

YES! An amazing overview of why prejudice, discrimination, and stereotyping might occur and the effects on marginalized groups. Not only is the topic so 
incredibly relevant to modern society but the professor and students have so many insightful viewpoints that not only helped me learn as a psychologist but as a member of diverse communities. Just take the class it's so good!

Maybe? In all honesty, I have been feeling disillusioned with psychology and I am not sure if social psychology/the psychology of prejudice answered the questions I was hoping to answer - more of an understanding of systemic oppression and the experiences of oppressed groups and less of cognitive explanations for why racists are racists. I know not all of my classmates felt the same way about this, and this is just my opinion, but I also found it strange to psychologically analyze/apply psychological concepts to real life events for the sake of class, when those events might have been traumatic for the people involved. For example, if I experienced a racially-motivated attack, I would find it upsetting to have my actions and my attacker's actions be psychoanalyzed by a group of strangers in a way that felt very detached, distanced, sterile, and academic.
Yes. Especially given current times, yes.

Absolutely. This is a class I'd been waiting to take for a while, and it did not disappoint. Prof. Richeson is a huge expert in this field, but she does an amazing job of explaining complex theories in ways that are easy to understand and make it clear how important they are to making sense of the things we experience in our lives. I also felt that she facilitated a really positive environment for self-reflection and created space for everyone to be able to work through their ideas. I am so glad I took this course, and I'd recommend it to anyone!
Yes I very much recommend this course! If you are looking for a way to understand prejudice and societal organization from a psychological perspective, this is the class for you.

Would recommend if you are interested in learning about social psychological models (e.g. Social Dominance Theory, Stereotype Content, Attribution Value, etc) and applying them to real world scenarios through careful research and analysis.

Definitely!! This class challenges you to see the issues we are facing from the lens of a social psychologist and pushes you to come up with ideas on how to combat prejudice, stereotyping and discrimination.

YES! Take anything with Prof Richeson. You'll learn as much from the way she approaches her course material as from the material itself. She is an incredibly kind, generous instructor, with a deep knowledge and passion for her subject that gets a class instantly engaged. The material was well organized and the feedback was great. One of the best psyc seminars at Yale.
